question: Will bluebird bio file for bankruptcy before April 1, 2025?
reasoning:
Based on the gathered evidence, Bluebird Bio has recently avoided bankruptcy by being acquired by private equity firms Carlyle Group and SK Capital Partners in a cash deal valued at $29 million. This acquisition was completed by the end of February 2025. The move to go private is seen as a strategy to avoid bankruptcy, allowing Bluebird Bio to focus on long-term development goals without the immediate pressure of public market demands. This suggests that the company has found a temporary resolution to its financial difficulties, at least in the short term.

Given this recent development, it is unlikely that Bluebird Bio will file for bankruptcy before April 1, 2025, as the acquisition provides a new financial structure and support to avoid such an outcome.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.1

Cheap-cheap? Bluebird dodges bankruptcy with $30M buyout
Feb. 21, 2025
By
Randy Osborne
Once high-flying Bluebird Bio Inc. has found a way out of its financial squeeze, as funds managed by global investment firms Carlyle and SK Capital Partners LP, along with a team of biotech executives, will be taking over the company.
BioWorld
Deals and M&A
Hematologic
U.S.

search_results.title: https://www.biospace.com/business/bluebirds-go-private-deal-highlights-fraught-life-preserver-for-struggling-biotechs
search_results.content:
---
title: Bluebird’s Go-Private Deal Highlights Fraught Life Preserver for Struggling Biotechs
author: Ana Mulero
url: https://www.biospace.com/business/bluebirds-go-private-deal-highlights-fraught-life-preserver-for-struggling-biotechs
hostname: biospace.com
description: Facing declining valuations and funding challenges, public biotechs like bluebird bio are going private to restructure, reduce regulatory burdens and refocus on long-term growth.
sitename: BioSpace
date: 2025-03-12
categories: ['Business, News']
tags: ['Mergers & acquisitions', 'BioPharm Executive', 'Featured', 'Feature', 'Bankruptcy', 'Gene therapy']
---
## Facing declining valuations and funding challenges, public biotechs like bluebird bio are going private to restructure, reduce regulatory burdens and refocus on long-term growth.

Bluebird bio’s recent decision to sell itself to private equity for a valuation of less than $30 million was a stunning outcome for a company that broke barriers in gene therapy. But bluebird isn’t alone, with a handful of biotechs recently striking go-private deals to avoid bankruptcy.

“Going private may allow biotech companies breathing room to focus on long-term development goals without the immediate pressure to deliver quarterly results,” Arda Ural, the Americas Life Sciences leader of Ernst & Young (EY), told *BioSpace*.

Bluebird was [ acquired by private equity firms](https://www.biospace.com/deals/bluebird-facing-cash-crunch-to-go-private-in-deal-valued-at-30m) Carlyle Group and SK Capital Partners in a cash deal valued at $29 million at the end of February. This followed a lengthy process in which the company explored strategic alternatives and admitted that it didn’t have enough cash to run past the first quarter of this year. Facing a

[, bluebird had to act. William Blair analysts said the move to go private was “likely inevitable.”](https://www.biospace.com/business/bluebird-faces-cash-gap-with-breakeven-point-in-sight)

__cash crunch__The board acknowledged that, absent a significant infusion of capital, the company risked defaulting, accoding to an investor note written by Jack Allen, senior research analyst at Baird. Bluebird made some mistakes along the way, particularly by stretching itself too thin pursuing international expansion for its pricey gene therapies, Allen said in an interview with *BioSpace*.

Privatization is still a rare strategy in the industry but can be a viable option for biotechs struggling with public market pressure…

messages.content:
Based on the following question, analyze it carefully and provide your probability estimate.

Question: Will bluebird bio file for bankruptcy before April 1, 2025?
Background: Reuters: [Bluebird bio to cut 25% of jobs in fresh bid to battle cash crunch](https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/bluebird-bio-cut-25-workforce-part-restructuring-2024-09-24/)
Resolution criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if bluebird bio, Inc., files any petition for bankruptcy protection in the United States, under any chapter of the United States Bankruptcy Code, before April 1, 2025. The question will resolves on the filing of such a petition, not on whether any bankruptcy protection is granted by a court. If no such petition is filed by that date, this question will resolve as **No**.
Fine print: 
present_date: 2025-03-18T04:36:06.830159


Make sure to use the tools at your disposal to gather relevant information before providing your final probability estimate.

You may reason through the problem, but you MUST end your response with:
FINAL PROBABILITY: [your decimal number between 0 and 1]

Cheap-cheap? Bluebird dodges bankruptcy with $30M buyout
Feb. 21, 2025
By
Randy Osborne
Once high-flying Bluebird Bio Inc. has found a way out of its financial squeeze, as funds managed by global investment firms Carlyle and SK Capital Partners LP, along with a team of biotech executives, will be taking over the company.
BioWorld
Deals and M&A
Hematologic
U.S.", "word_count": 245, "snippet_word_count": 245, "snippet_truncated": false, "date_cutoff_start": "2025-02-18T04:36:06.830159", "date_cutoff_end": "2025-03-19T04:36:06.830159", "cached_at": "2025-10-24T06:30:27.895115"}

messages.content:
{"url": "https://www.biospace.com/business/bluebirds-go-private-deal-highlights-fraught-life-preserver-for-struggling-biotechs", "snippet": "---
title: Bluebird’s Go-Private Deal Highlights Fraught Life Preserver for Struggling Biotechs
author: Ana Mulero
url: https://www.biospace.com/business/bluebirds-go-private-deal-highlights-fraught-life-preserver-for-struggling-biotechs
hostname: biospace.com
description: Facing declining valuations and funding challenges, public biotechs like bluebird bio are going private to restructure, reduce regulatory burdens and refocus on long-term growth.
sitename: BioSpace
date: 2025-03-12
categories: ['Business, News']
tags: ['Mergers & acquisitions', 'BioPharm Executive', 'Featured', 'Feature', 'Bankruptcy', 'Gene therapy']
---
## Facing declining valuations and funding challenges, public biotechs like bluebird bio are going private to restructure, reduce regulatory burdens and refocus on long-term growth.

Bluebird bio’s recent decision to sell itself to private equity for a valuation of less than $30 million was a stunning outcome for a company that broke barriers in gene therapy. But bluebird isn’t alone, with a handful of biotechs recently striking go-private deals to avoid bankruptcy.

“Going private may allow biotech companies breathing room to focus on long-term development goals without the immediate pressure to deliver quarterly results,” Arda Ural, the Americas Life Sciences leader of Ernst & Young (EY), told *BioSpace*.

Bluebird was [ acquired by private equity firms](https://www.biospace.com/deals/bluebird-facing-cash-crunch-to-go-private-in-deal-valued-at-30m) Carlyle Group and SK Capital Partners in a cash deal valued at $29 million at the end of February. This followed a lengthy process in which the company explored strategic alternatives and admitted that it didn’t have enough cash to run past the first quarter of this year. Facing a

[, bluebird had to act. William Blair analysts said the move to go private was “likely inevitable.”](https://www.biospace.com/business/bluebird-faces-cash-gap-with-breakeven-point-in-sight)

__cash crunch__The board acknowledged that, absent a significant infusion of capital, the company risked defaulting, accoding to an investor note written by Jack Allen, senior research analyst at Baird. Bluebird made some mistakes along the way, particularly by stretching itself too thin pursuing international expansion for its pricey gene therapies, Allen said in an interview with *BioSpace*.

Privatization is still a rare strategy in the industry but can be a viable option for biotechs struggling with public market pressure…

[Truncated preview: showing 325 words out of ~1334. Full content available via `btf_extract_evidence`.]", "word_count": 1334, "snippet_word_count": 325, "snippet_truncated": true, "date_cutoff_start": "2025-02-18T04:36:06.830159", "date_cutoff_end": "2025-03-19T04:36:06.830159", "cached_at": "2025-10-24T06:30:28.332095"}

messages.content:
Based on the gathered evidence, Bluebird Bio has recently avoided bankruptcy by being acquired by private equity firms Carlyle Group and SK Capital Partners in a cash deal valued at $29 million. This acquisition was completed by the end of February 2025. The move to go private is seen as a strategy to avoid bankruptcy, allowing Bluebird Bio to focus on long-term development goals without the immediate pressure of public market demands. This suggests that the company has found a temporary resolution to its financial difficulties, at least in the short term.

Given this recent development, it is unlikely that Bluebird Bio will file for bankruptcy before April 1, 2025, as the acquisition provides a new financial structure and support to avoid such an outcome.

FINAL PROBABILITY: 0.1
